newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila, U.S. officials meet on pork dispute.
newsitem.headline: Manila, U.S. officials meet on pork dispute.

text.p: Three U.S. legislators on Thursday urged Manila to fulfil its promise to the World Trade Organisation on fair market access for pork.

"At this point, there has been a flexibility and an opening of the frozen market in the Philippines," Bob Smith, chairman of the U.S. House committee on Agriculture, told reporters after meeting with Philippine President Fidel Ramos.
U.S. meat producers have complained to the trade body that the Philippines blocked fair market access for U.S. pork.
Smith, together with Representatives Bill Barrett and Richard Pombo, said his group is set to discuss the complaints with Philippine agriculture ministry officials.
"That (minimum import of frozen pork) was an agreement when the Philippines became part of WTO," Smith said. "It's a matter of fulfilling a promise and a requirement."
Manila allowed imports of up to 49,000 tonnes in 1996 but Philippine livestock companies imported only about 2,500 tonnes.
Philippine Agriculture Secretary Salvador Escudero reiterated that low imports were because Filipinos did not like the taste of frozen pork.
"I assured them that we are just as interested in having frozen pork accepted in the domestic market," Escudero told reporters.
Meanwhile, Escudero said he had asked the U.S. legislators to help Philippine mangoes enter the U.S. market.
The Philippines import U.S. wheat, corn, apples and citrus fruit.
